conclusion: The problem involves calculating the gravitational force exerted by the remaining part of a sphere (after a smaller sphere is removed) on a point mass located at a distance of 2R from the center of the original sphere.
The principle of superposition and the formula for gravitational force will be used to solve the problem.
The gravitational force due to the original sphere of mass M and radius R on the point mass m located at a distance of 2R is given by F_original = G * (M * m) / (2R)^2 = G * (M * m) / (4R^2).
The volume of the original sphere is V_original = (4/3) * π * R^3.
The volume of the removed sphere is V_removed = (4/3) * π * (R/2)^3 = (4/3) * π * (R^3 / 8) = (1/6) * π * R^3.
The ratio of the volumes of the removed sphere to the original sphere is V_removed / V_original = [(1/6) * π * R^3] / [(4/3) * π * R^3] = 1/8.
The mass of the removed sphere is M_removed = (1/8) * M.
The mass of the remaining part of the sphere is M_remaining = M - M_removed = M - (1/8) * M = (7/8) * M.
The gravitational force due to the remaining part of the sphere on the point mass m is F_remaining = G * (M_remaining * m) / (2R)^2 = G * [(7/8) * M * m] / (4R^2) = G * (7 * M * m) / (32R^2).
The gravitational force due to the removed part of the sphere on the point mass m is F_removed = G * (M_removed * m) / (2R)^2 = G * [(1/8) * M * m] / (4R^2) = G * (M * m) / (32R^2).

Using the principle of superposition, the net gravitational force F is the difference between the gravitational force due to the original sphere and the gravitational force due to the removed part: F = F_original - F_removed.

premise: F_original = G * (M * m) / (4R^2), F_removed = G * (M * m) / (32R^2)
